comment._content: Streetview

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: OSI 25" from 1907.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Wikipedia In 1899, the company introduced the trademark Oxo for a cheaper version; the origin of the name is unknown, but presumably comes from the word 'ox'. The first Oxo cubes were produced in 1910 and further increased Oxo's popularity, as the cubes were cheaper than the liquid.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Intriguing - You would have to think that all the onlookers were not there by accident, it must have something to do with a well advertised event.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A1 Sauce is from 1873, no help.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: On the OS 25", you can see Montpelier Barrack RAMC, just up Infirmary Road as well as the Royal Military Infirmary. Royal Army Medical Corps. The last of these wagons has a big cross on it - I think they are ambulances.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Uniforms look right at first glance: www.users.globalnet.co.uk/~thinred/collection/Quartermast...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Could be a complete red herring, but found this in an article about the use of canal boats for troop movement. Describes various Brigades travelling along the Grand Canal to Naas... This is the meaty (or herringy bit maybe): "Two officers and 104 men of other ranks of the Royal Army Medical Corps left Kingsbridge in the afternoon for Newbridge." (Irish Independent of Wednesday, 8 September 1909)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
I don't think they are all ambulances since the red cross marked wagon is behind the rearguard escort to the convoy in front. I would suggest the ambulance is following the convoy? It also appears to be turning left into Infirmary Road. The front of the convoy has stopped for some reason.

The Royal Irish Regiment and Royal Irish Fusiliers were both based at Parkgate at Phoenix Park. The uniforms look like the Royal Irish Regiment. However they may also be Royal Irish Constabulary as the uniforms look similar and their training depot was also at Phoenix Park.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Almost everyone is walking (Cycling, Driving) away from the Phoenix Park. So I presume the aftermath of some event there? Something like - First recruits to the Irish Citizen Army drilling in the Phoenix Park, December 1913. James Connolly is second from the right. multitext.ucc.ie/viewgallery/356 OR King George visit in June 1911?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: I think 1913 is too late.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] If this was right I would expect that the wagons would have delivered troops to Heuston and would be on their way back to Parkgate so the empty convoy would be approaching the photographer rather than going away?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] the lower back panel on the jackets is different to Medical ones.....the RIC actually looks the best fit so far.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] You're right. Just thought I'd throw it out there...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Not R.I.C. I think, the constabulary had blackened helmet plates and buttons etc. The officers on horseback at the rear might be Royal Artillery, Army Service Corps, Royal Army Medical Corps or the Army Veterinary Corps as their helmets appear to have a ball instead of a spike on top similar to this one 1878 pattern artillery helmet Some more on the Home service helmet here www.militarysunhelmets.com/2013/the-british-home-service-...

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: During the Great War my Grand Mother from Cork was a volunteer with the R.A.M.C. as an aide!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] the lower back panel on the jackets is wrong for RAMC

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06/] Artillery maybe? similar tunic detail on this one Army Service Corps had the same detail also apparently.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] only two buttons on each side where RHA has three.....

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: Ah, breaker one-nine, this here's the Rubber Duck. Mercy sakes alive, looks like we got us a convoy...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06/] I'm not convinced the officers tunics have only 2 buttons, very hard to be sure given the lack of detail. My money would be on Royal Artillery or Army Service Corps and they might have been heading to the Mobilization Stores further up Parkgate Street. The soldiers riding in the wagon are probably an armed guard of infantry and if I was to guess a date I would say prior to 1905 and possibly during the Boer War between 1899 and 1902. Nice model of a Royal Army Service Corps wagon sold at Bonhams www.bonhams.com/auctions/16764/lot/29/ R.A.M.C. officers did have the 3 buttons on the back of the tunic similar to artillery and army service corps. RAMC officers uniform

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: There must have been something on in the park? Mostly men and all very well dressed and most are heading back into town. Possibly a Sunday Polo meeting. Electric street lamps of a type post 1903. NLI catalog photo L_ROY_08906 taken earlier same day( window, curtain and blind settings match), street is quieter and there is a car with a reg plate. The Motor Car Act 1903, which came into force on 1 January 1904, required all motor vehicles to carry number plates. Moving up--- Ryans Public House built 1905 archiseek.com/2010/ryans-parkgate-street-dublin/

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: My guess was funeral procession.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: DeBurgh Terrace and DeBurgh Road, that now occupy the site on and behind the OXO hoarding, had been built and all the houses occupied by 2nd April 1911.( Building Return). Considering that it would take about a year to build these houses and as there's no evidence of them on the 1907 map either I suspect this photo dates from between 1907 and 1909.

comment.author: 41052173@N02
comment._content: dah - Black Friday!
